entry.title: Combined summary - Compressed Bitcoin Transactions
entry.summary:
Tom has refined the Bitcoin transaction compression schema and submitted a draft PR to the Bitcoin Core repository. The updated schema introduces key changes, such as the use of relative block height for Compressed Inputs and a new type of Variable Integer.
The goal of the Compressed Transaction Schema is to minimize transaction sizes through various strategies like metadata packing, replacing 32-bit values with variable-length integers, compressed signatures, public key recovery, and using block height and output index instead of the txid/vout pair. This approach could lead to issues if block reorganizations affect the transactions unless inputs are sufficiently old.
The schema incorporates encoding techniques such as CompactSize and VarInts for numerical efficiency and VLP-Bytestreams for length definition. It also details metadata fields for transactions and their components, optimizing data management related to versions, counts, lock times, and block heights.
Designed to aid in bandwidth-limited applications like steganography and satellite/radio broadcasting, the schema allows for reversible compression, barring Txid/Vout pairs, and accommodates transactions shaped for better compressibility. The ideal transaction for maximum compression is specified, showcasing savings in various transaction fields. Test vectors indicate the schema's effectiveness with Taproot and Legacy transactions.
For more information and access to the reference implementation, Tom's GitHub pull request can be found at: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/29134.
In parallel, Fabian has explored the possibility of a sorted UTXO set index to save space and support pruning. He suggests adding a height parameter for proper referencing and considers alternatives like composite references or short hashes, though acknowledging Tom's scheme might be more space-efficient. The assumeutxo concept paired with a pre-agreed height is another potential direction.
Andrew has recognized Tom's work and requested a chart comparing uncompressed and compressed transaction sizes for various types, emphasizing the need for data on prevalent transactions such as 2-in-2-out wpkh and Taproot, as well as less common ones like p2sh-wpkh and p2pkh.
Tom's contribution is focused on bitcoin transaction compression suitable for low-bandwidth communication but requiring high CPU availability for decompression, ensuring transactions remain intact during the process. His commitment is reflected in the submission of the draft PR for his compression schema.
